articles.headline: ‘How I Met Your Mother’ Gets Its Best Ratings for Finale
articles.snippet: After nine years, the CBS comedy tried to wrap up its many loose ends Monday night. The audience of 12.9 million was the show’s largest.
articles.abstract: After nine years, the CBS comedy tried to wrap up its many loose ends Monday night. The audience of 12.9 million was the show’s largest.
articles.lead_paragraph: CBS’s hit comedy “How I Met Your Mother” exited to what amounted to a standing ovation on Monday night — from viewers, if not critics — scoring the best ratings in the show’s nine-season history.

articles.headline: Obama Claims Victory in Push for Insurance
articles.snippet: The announcement that 7.1 million people had signed up for plans under the Affordable Care Act came as the Obama administration braced for an escalated political battle ahead of the midterm elections.
articles.abstract: The announcement that 7.1 million people had signed up for plans under the Affordable Care Act came as the Obama administration braced for an escalated political battle ahead of the midterm elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama declared victory Tuesday in the government’s aggressive push to enroll seven million people in private health insurance plans under the Affordable Care Act, even as his senior aides braced for an escalated political battle over the law ahead of the fall’s crucial midterm elections.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Robert Pear

articles.headline: Steelhead Drive Is Gone After Mudslide, Along With Many Lives Lived on It
articles.snippet: The Ruthvens, the Satterlees, the Spillers and the Halsteads, among many families now presumed dead after the landslide in Oso, Wash., defined their neighborhood with their lives.
articles.abstract: The Ruthvens, the Satterlees, the Spillers and the Halsteads, among many families now presumed dead after the landslide in Oso, Wash., defined their neighborhood with their lives.
articles.lead_paragraph: OSO, Wash. — The words, recorded by the Snohomish County emergency response system in the frantic minutes after a giant wall of earth slid down the mountain here on the morning of March 22, were breathy and labored. “All the homes on Steelhead Drive are gone,” a man said with long pauses between his words.
articles.byline: By Kirk Johnson, Jack Healy and Ian Lovett

articles.headline: G.M. Hires Lawyer Specializing in Disaster Payouts
articles.snippet: Kenneth Feinberg, who oversaw compensation after 9/11 and the BP oil spill, will help in deliberations over whether to pay damages to victims of accidents in cars with faulty ignition switches.
articles.abstract: Kenneth Feinberg, who oversaw compensation after 9/11 and the BP oil spill, will help in deliberations over whether to pay damages to victims of accidents in cars with faulty ignition switches.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As families of crash victims lined the back of the House hearing room, displaying photos of their lost loved ones, Mary T. Barra, the General Motors chief executive, told lawmakers that the company was considering paying damages to victims of accidents in the millions of cars recalled for defective ignition switches.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Matthew L. Wald

articles.headline: Tap to Pay (Not So Much in the U.S.)
articles.snippet: Using smartphones to make payments for transit, food, clothing or even to pay bills is commonplace overseas but is not as widespread in the United States because of costs.
articles.abstract: Using smartphones to make payments for transit, food, clothing or even to pay bills is commonplace overseas but is not as widespread in the United States because of costs.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Science fiction writers have long envisioned a cashless society. But some places have taken bigger steps in that direction than others.
articles.byline: By Chad Bray and Reuben Kyama

articles.headline: Old Forecast of Famine May Yet Come True
articles.snippet: As crop yields fall and populations rise, the alarming vision of Thomas Malthus might be proved right by climate change — two centuries after he first expressed it.
articles.abstract: As crop yields fall and populations rise, the alarming vision of Thomas Malthus might be proved right by climate change — two centuries after he first expressed it.
articles.lead_paragraph: Might Thomas Malthus be vindicated in the end?

articles.headline: A Revolution in Money
articles.snippet: Futurists predict a revolution in the tenets of finance in the coming decades, similar to the changes that have been sweeping the information and telecommunications industries.
articles.abstract: Futurists predict a revolution in the tenets of finance in the coming decades, similar to the changes that have been sweeping the information and telecommunications industries.

articles.headline: A Billion-Dollar Bracelet Is the Key to a Disney Park
articles.snippet: Disney is counting on its multifaceted reservation system to ease the way to visit Mickey Mouse and company.
articles.abstract: Disney is counting on its multifaceted reservation system to ease the way to visit Mickey Mouse and company.
articles.lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Walt Disney World has spent more than a year rolling out a $1 billion system that changes how visitors do everything from enter their hotel rooms to ride Space Mountain. But a few weeks ago a front desk agent at one of Disney’s marquee hotels was still wrestling with the technology.

articles.headline: Police Confront Rising Number of Mentally Ill Suspects
articles.snippet: In towns and cities across the United States, police officers find themselves playing dual roles as law enforcers and psychiatric social workers.
articles.abstract: In towns and cities across the United States, police officers find themselves playing dual roles as law enforcers and psychiatric social workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALBUQUERQUE — James Boyd, a homeless man camping in the Sandia Foothills here, could hear the commands of the police officers who were trying to move him out.
articles.byline: By Fernanda Santos and Erica Goode

articles.headline: Bishops Follow Pope’s Example: Opulence Is Out
articles.snippet: Backlash to a plan by Archbishop Wilton D. Gregory of Atlanta to build a large mansion is the latest in a series of lay uprisings since Pope Francis chose to live in a modest residence.
articles.abstract: Backlash to a plan by Archbishop Wilton D. Gregory of Atlanta to build a large mansion is the latest in a series of lay uprisings since Pope Francis chose to live in a modest residence.
articles.lead_paragraph: The archbishop of Atlanta had a plan to resolve the space crunch at his cathedral: He would move out of his residence so priests could move in, and then he would build himself a new house with donated money and land.

articles.headline: Afghan Women See Hope in the Ballot Box
articles.snippet: There’s finally a sense that women have become a significant part of Afghanistan’s political life, but many fear the gains could be reversed if extremists retake power or Western aid dwindles.
articles.abstract: There’s finally a sense that women have become a significant part of Afghanistan’s political life, but many fear the gains could be reversed if extremists retake power or Western aid dwindles.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Mariam Wardak is one of those young Afghans with her feet in two worlds: At 28, she has spent much of her adult life in Afghanistan, but she grew up in the United States after her family fled there. She vividly remembers the culture shock of visits back to her family’s village in rural Wardak Province a decade ago.

articles.headline: To Curtail Departures, SAC Pursues 2-Year Pacts
articles.snippet: Steven A. Cohen is asking employees who remain with his family office to sign two-year contracts.
articles.abstract: Steven A. Cohen is asking employees who remain with his family office to sign two-year contracts.
articles.lead_paragraph: The billionaire investor Steven A. Cohen is putting pressure on his traders to try to keep his investment firm together, as the once-powerful hedge fund awaits a judge’s decision next week on its guilty plea to securities fraud charges.

articles.headline: If You Like Immersion, You’ll Love This Reality
articles.snippet: Jeremy Bailenson, who directs Stanford’s Virtual Human Interaction Lab, says virtual reality is the natural extension of every major technology being used today.
articles.abstract: Jeremy Bailenson, who directs Stanford’s Virtual Human Interaction Lab, says virtual reality is the natural extension of every major technology being used today.
articles.lead_paragraph: The news that Facebook paid $2 billion for a virtual reality start-up, Oculus VR, might strike you as a bit zany. Like flying cars and robotic maids, the idea of donning a pair of computerized glasses and slipping into a digital world feels like a snapshot from yesterday’s future.

articles.headline: Supreme Court Strikes Down Overall Political Donation Cap
articles.snippet: The decision let stand familiar base limits on contributions from individuals to candidates, but it said that overall limits for contributions to all federal candidates violated the First Amendment.
articles.abstract: The decision let stand familiar base limits on contributions from individuals to candidates, but it said that overall limits for contributions to all federal candidates violated the First Amendment.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Wednesday continued its abolition of limits on election spending, striking down a decades-old cap on the total amount any individual can contribute to federal candidates in a two-year election cycle.

articles.headline: G.M. Chief Faces Ire of Senators in Hearing
articles.snippet: Setting the tone for Wednesday’s questioning of Mary T. Barra, the chief of General Motors, Senator Claire McCaskill said the company had a “culture of cover-up” that discouraged quick action to fix a defective part.
articles.abstract: Setting the tone for Wednesday’s questioning of Mary T. Barra, the chief of General Motors, Senator Claire McCaskill said the company had a “culture of cover-up” that discouraged quick action to fix a defective part.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The questions came faster and harder at Mary T. Barra on Wednesday.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Matthew L. Wald
